oai_dc:dc.dc:title: LOW LATITUDE TYPHOON INDUCED STORM TIDE IN SINGAPORE: A MONTE CARLO APPROACH FOR STORM TIDE MODELLING
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Tay, Serene Hui Xin
Trinh, Dieu Huong
Ooi, Seng Keat
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Within 5 degrees of the Equator, it has been known as the cyclone-free zone due to insufficient Earthâ€™s background rotation to support vortex spin-up (Anthes, 1982). However, Steenkamp et al. (2018) pointed out that there are about 213 tropical cyclones formed between 5oN and 5oS during the period 1900-2017 based on the International Best Track Archive for Climate Stewardship (IBTrACS) (Knapp et al., 2010). In this paper, we attempt to develop a statistical model to characterize all historical low latitude typhoons recorded and generate a population of synthetic typhoons near Singapore. Thereafter we simulate extreme storm tide (combined typhoon-induced surge and tide) events in Singapore using these Monte Carlo simulated synthetic typhoons and a hydrodynamic tidal model to determine the maximum storm tide around Singapore.
oai_dc:dc.dc:source: Coastal Engineering Proceedings; No. 38 (2024): Proceedings of 38th Conference on Coastal Engineering, Rome, Italy, 2024; management.203
